definition:
A set $A$ is called *inhabited*, if there exists an element $a\in A$.
Note that in classical mathematics this is equivalent to
$A\neq\emptyset$ (i.e. $A$ being nonempty), yet in intuitionistic
mathematics we actually have to find an element $a\in A$. For example
the set, which contains $1$ if Goldbach’s conjecture is true and $0$ if
it is false is certainly nonempty, yet by today’s state of knowledge we
cannot say if $A$ is inhabited, since we do not know an element of $A$.
